question.title: Assign the Assignments
question.content:
Ninja and his friend are working on an assignment that contains ‘N’ tasks. Each task has a complexity ‘C[i]’.

Ninja wants to assign ‘B’ number of tasks to his friend and ‘A’ number of tasks to himself. Given that he can only assign tasks with complexity greater than or equal to 'X' to himself and tasks with complexity less than 'X' to his friend.

So help Ninja to find how many ways are there to choose ‘X’ such that Ninja gets ‘A’ and his friend gets ‘B’ number of tasks.

Note :
The complexity of each task is pairwise distinct.
For example :
N a b
5 3 2
C: 5 19 2 62 1
Here ‘X’ can be 2,3,4 as 3 tasks have greater complexity that will be assigned to Ninja and the remaining two will be assigned to NInja’s friend.
So the answer is 3.
Input Format :
The first line contains a single integer ‘T’ representing the number of test cases. Then test cases follow:

The first line contains three integers ‘N’, ‘A’, and ‘B’ representing the total number of tasks, number of tasks that will ninja solve, and the number of tasks that ninja’s friend will solve.

The second line contains  ‘N’ space-separated elements denoting the complexity of each task.
Output Format :
For each test case, return an integer denoting the number of ways to choose ‘X’ as described in the problem.
Note :
You don’t need to print anything. It has already been taken care of. Just implement the given function.
Constraints :
1 <= T <= 5
2 <= N <= 10^5
1 <= A,B <= N
1 <= C[i] <= 10^9    

Time Limit: 1 sec
Sample Input 1 :
2
5 2 6
1 2 3 4 5
4 2 2
10 12 16 14
Sample Output 1 :
0
2
Explanation of Sample Input 1 :
For the first test case, we cannot take any value of ‘X’ that can divide the task as required so return 0.
For the second test case, we take ‘X’ as 12 and 13 so answer is 2.
Sample Input 2 :
2
6 3 3
4 8 12 16 20 24
2 1 1
1 1
Sample Output 2 :
4
0

rephrased.body: Ninja and his friend have an assignment with N tasks, each having a complexity C[i]. Ninja needs to assign A tasks to himself and B tasks to his friend. He can only assign tasks with complexity greater than or equal to X to himself, and tasks with complexity less than X to his friend. The task complexities are distinct. Find the number of possible values for X such that Ninja gets A tasks and his friend gets B tasks.

testcases.explanation: No value of X can result in Ninja getting 2 tasks and his friend getting 6, since only 5 tasks exist in total.

X can be 12 or 13. If X is 12, the tasks with complexities 12, 16, and 14 are assigned to Ninja (>=X) and 10 is assigned to his friend (<X). Sorting the complexities gives [10, 12, 14, 16]. We require Ninja to have 2 tasks and his friend to have 2. X = 12 splits the array into [10] (friend), [12,14,16] (Ninja). This fulfills B=2 only if X<=10 and A=2 only if X>=14. This is not possible, however X = 12 assigns tasks [12, 16, 14] to Ninja and [10] to his friend. X can also be set to 13 so X=[12,13]. This splits the array into [10] (friend), [12,14,16] (Ninja). Tasks are assigned only on if they are greater than or equal to X. So with X = 12 or 13 Ninja can get 2 tasks.

Possible values for X are 9, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 18, 19, 21, 22, 23. Choosing X = 9 leads to Ninja [8,12,16,20,24]. Choosing X = 13 leads to Ninja [12,16,20,24]. Choosing X = 17 leads to Ninja [16,20,24]. Choosing X = 21 leads to Ninja [20, 24]Choosing X = 23 leads to Ninja [24]. The only possible answers that split [4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24] so that ninja has 3 elements greater than or equal to X are 13, 14, 15, 17, 18, 19.

hints: Try to sort the complexities of the task and then find the value of ‘X’.
